message: Congratulations to Midland's own Joe Kaczynski for winning the gold medal in the 5K Freestyle Cross Country race at the Special Olympics in Austria on Monday!

I had the opportunity to speak with Midwest Alliance of Sovereign Tribes. The president of the alliance is the Fourth District's own Frank Cloutier, the chief of the Saginaw Chippewa Indian Tribe. I was happy to speak with the group and hear about the issues tribes in our region are facing.
Congratulations to Mount Pleasant, Michigan on its 128th birthday today! Here's more history from the Morning Sun:

This week I have had meetings about issues in college education. I met with students from Central Michigan University and they shared their stories about being the first ones in their families to go to college. I also had a meeting with President Thomas Haas of Grand Valley State University. #Fireupchips #anchorup

Farmers from the Fourth District visited my office last week and we talked about the issues they are facing this year, including burdensome regulations, and tax reform. You can watch this video from Michigan Farm Bureau to see my comments and those of other members from Michigan.
Good luck to Buckley Community School PTO tomorrow when it plays for the state championship in boys basketball!

FRIDAY DEADLINE: I am currently accepting applications for congressional internships in my Washington, D.C. office for summer 2017. The internship program is open to college students and recent graduates who are interested in learning more about our country’s legislative process and the day-to-day operations of a congressional office. Intern responsibilities include conducting tours of the U.S. Capitol, constituent data entry, researching federal legislation and assisting legislative staff. Interns will also have the opportunity to attend legislative briefings, congressional hearings and receptions on Capitol Hill. Applicants are asked to provide a cover letter, resume and any specific legislative issues or areas of interest. Applications should be submitted by close of business on Friday, March 31. For more information and to apply for the summer semester, please visit https://moolenaar.house.gov/internships

Over the weekend, farmers came together in Morrice in Shiawassee County to send feed and other supplies to those who have been hurt by wildfires in western states. Farmers across Michigan have been so generous, and I pray that all those participating in the convoys have safe travels.

I had a great meeting this afternoon with the Michigan 4-H State Youth Leadership Group. 4-H inspires a new generation of leaders in agriculture and it does terrific work in communities across the Fourth District.

Bipartisanship today on Capitol Hill as Congressman Dan Kildee and I welcomed students from Central Michigan University to the Capitol. I am proud to represent CMU in the House and I know Congressman Kildee is proud to be a Chippewa alum. I hope the students had a great tour of the Capitol building and enjoy their visit to Washington. #FireUpChips
Good morning from Owosso where I just spoke with the Shiawassee County Farm Bureau about the latest issues in agriculture.

I hope you will like and share this important information about my support for the Great Lakes with your friends and neighbors who may be hearing otherwise.   As a member of the Appropriations Committee, I will be working across the aisle with my colleagues on the committee to fund the Great Lakes Restoration Initiative. The GLRI has always enjoyed strong bipartisan support in Congress and I want to thank my 63 colleagues who recently signed a letter to the committee signaling their strong support for this funding.   If you would like to read more about my efforts for protecting the Great Lakes, particularly from invasive species and nuclear waste, please read my recent op-ed.

Last Friday was Jack Telfer's last day at the Midland Daily News. Jack has been at the paper since 1991 and last year he led it to the Michigan Newspaper Association's Newspaper of the Year Award! I have honored Jack and his contributions to our community with a special tribute in the Congressional Record. All the best to Jack in retirement!

The deadline for the annual Congressional Art Competition is two weeks away, on April 17. The winning student will have his or her art displayed in the U.S. Capitol for a year and receive two round-trip tickets to travel to Washington, D.C for an annual event with competition winners from around the country. Regional winners from the Fourth District will have the opportunity for their art to appear in the Midland and Cadillac offices. See the link for more details and please encourage talented high school artists you know to enter the competition.

Brian Sabourin from Midland stopped by the office today. He is the Director of Employment Services at Michigan Protection and Advocacy Service and he shared with me the good work his organization does to help people with disabilities find career opportunities.

Joshua Jacobson, the winner of the Congressional App Challenge for our district, was on Capitol Hill today and he presented his app alongside other winners from across the country. Joshua made the trip with his parents and he talked to me about the big difference robotics and coding have made in his life. Congratulations Joshua!
Congratulations to the 1460th Transportation Company on being a finalist for top maintenance honors!

Today, another farm convoy left Michigan to help who have been affected by wildfires in America's heartland. I spoke about the overwhelming and generous efforts of the Michigan farming community in response to this crisis. I pray for God's blessing on all involved as they continue to help our fellow Americans.

Earlier this week Bashar al-Assad's horrific use of chemical weapons slaughtered innocent children in Syria. Last night's U.S. military strike on Assad's airfield carried out by our brave men and women damages his ability to perpetrate future atrocities and is a strong signal that the United States will not accept his brutal use of chemical weapons.

Thank you to Doug Bartlett of Edmore for inviting me to join him for a ride along on his mail route today. Doug is also the president of the Michigan Rural Letter Carriers Association (MIRLCA) and we had a great discussion regarding USPS issues today.

SEVEN DAYS TO GO: The deadline for the annual Congressional Art Competition is two weeks away, on April 17. The winning student will have his or her art displayed in the U.S. Capitol for a year and receive two round-trip tickets to travel to Washington, D.C for an annual event with competition winners from around the country. Regional winners from the Fourth District will have the opportunity for their art to appear in the Midland and Cadillac offices. See the link for more details and please encourage talented high school artists you know to enter the competition.
Happy Easter!
May you and your family have a blessed Good Friday.
Thank you to the Embassy of the Netherlands in the United States for the tulips today to celebrate Dutch American Friendship Day!

Today, I presented the National Defense Service Medal, the Korean Service Medal and the United Nations Medal to Korean War Veteran Peter Zolin of Houghton Lake. It was a great event and I am glad his family could join us for this special occasion.

NEW STATE RECORD: Congratulations to Amber Gall of Shepherd High School on setting a new state record in the 800 meters! It is a great accomplishment.The previous record had stood for 37 years. Best wishes for continued success!
I enjoyed some Flint coney dogs for lunch today thanks to Congressman Dan Kildee recently making good on our bet for last year's Congressional Baseball Game.

This morning, I presented Vietnam War Commemorative Lapel Pins to Vietnam veterans at American Legion Post 212 Chesaning MI. Thank-you to Post Commander Rod Toma and his great group of veterans for a terrific morning.
Great to meet with University of Michigan President Mark Schlissel today to talk about the importance of research funding for the National Institutes of Health (NIH). #GoBlue

Today, the president signed an executive order creating an executive branch task force to study the burdens the federal government imposes on farmers. Farmers are our best conservationists and they work hard to put food on the tables of families in our state and around the world. Overregulation has burdened agriculture and more can be done to help hardworking Michigan farmers like those in the milk and sugar industries who have been hurt by unfair trade practices. I hope this task force will find common-sense solutions to reform government and help a vital part of our state’s economy.

Yesterday, I attended a briefing with officials from the Army Corps of Engineers and other agencies about the delayed release of the Brandon Road Lock and Dam report on stopping invasive species. As I told the Detroit News today, “we want a long-term strategy that we can implement quickly and have a permanent solution. That’s where this recommendation is so important. That’s why we’re urging the release of this report."

Congratulations to the Trevino triplets on their outstanding academic accomplishments at Bath High School. Best wishes for continued success as they attend Central Michigan University together. #fireupchips
Had a great day with family yesterday celebrating my son's birthday!

This week is Small Business Week, which recognizes the enormous contributions America's 29 million small businesses make to our economy. I was in Shiawassee County last week where I attended the ribbon cutting ceremony for Great Lakes Rental and Supply and talked with owner Bryan Marks about the issues small businesses face. It's great to see companies investing in mid Michigan.

Thanks to all of the talented artists from across the district who entered the Congressional Art Competition this year. The artwork was outstanding! This year's winner is Lydia Hershauer of Herbert Henry Dow High School for her charcoal portrait, titled "Jackie." Congratulations!
Stopped in Gaylord for dinner where everyone is all in for hometown girl Lauren Duski on The Voice. She had an amazing performance tonight. Go Lauren!

Michigan's own Joan Larsen is an outstanding choice for the federal Sixth Circuit Court of Appeals. She will serve as a rule of law judge and her decisions will be guided by the Constitution. I hope the Senate will confirm her nomination promptly.
Happy Mother's Day!

North Korea conducted another missile test over the weekend. These tests are part of North Korea's attempts to threaten our country and that is why earlier this month, I voted for stronger sanctions that will protect the American people and support efforts to stop North Korea.
Congratulations to Sacred Heart Academy High School on its Quiz Central division championship. Good luck tomorrow in the semifinals!

Agriculture Secretary Sonny Perdue testified before Congress this week about the state of the rural economy and the 2018 farm bill. These are important issues for our state's farmers and rural communities and I will continue to advocate for policies in next year's farm bill that benefit Michigan agriculture.

Tax reform done right will benefit Michigan residents of all income levels, by making it easier for them to calculate and file their tax returns while lowering their tax burden. Today, I spoke on the floor about updating our tax code for the first time since 1986. It's time for a simpler, fairer and flatter tax system.

This week brought thousands of police officers to the Capitol to mark Police Week. In honor of this, the House passed legislation to protect our state and local law enforcement officers. I am so grateful for all the law enforcement officers in mid and northern Michigan who put their lives on the line to keep all of us safe. Thank you for your hard work and sacrifice.
Congratulations to Allison Boyd from Clare Middle School for winning the WCFX-FM Morning Sun Spelling Bee on Wednesday!

Last night’s horrific attack on children in Manchester is a tragic reminder of the terrorist threat we and our allies face. Please pray for the injured, and especially for the families of the victims. May they find comfort and peace in this time of mourning.
Forever grateful for every American who made the ultimate sacrifice for our country.

Flags-In is a special way to remember the men and women who made the ultimate sacrifice. Our fallen heroes gave their last full measure of devotion in service to our country and we can never do enough to honor their memories.
Yesterday I spoke at the Midland Memorial Day Service. It was wonderful to see so many people come and pay tribute to the men and women who gave their all for our country.

The iron ore that passes through the Soo Locks is used in automobiles, appliances, agriculture, and construction. While the Locks are vital to the national economy, they are also vulnerable to a major disruption that would increase unemployment nationwide. To protect good-paying jobs we need to build a new lock, so the materials powering our economy can continue to move through the Soo for years to come. Rep. Jack Bergman and I have more details in the Detroit News this week.
Thanks to the Shiawassee Regional Chamber of Commerce for hosting this event on Tuesday afternoon in Corunna. Enjoyed the good discussion about the legislative issues of the day.
On Saturday, I gave the commencement address to the graduating home school class of 2017. Congratulations and best wishes!

Today is the 73rd anniversary of D-Day, the Allied effort to storm the beaches of France and defeat the Nazis. The Normandy American Cemetery and Memorial is a moving reminder of the enormous sacrifice made to defeat tyranny and liberate a continent.

Today, I co-sponsored legislation introduced in the House of Representatives by Rep. Jack Bergman to authorize construction of a new lock at the Soo Locks. We have been working on this issue together and we recently wrote an op-ed about it that you might have seen in your local paper. The Soo Locks are vital to our country. We need to improve the 50-year old infrastructure and build a new lock to grow the economy and protect good-paying jobs for hardworking Michigan residents.

Today the House passed the Financial Choice Act. This legislation benefits everyday Americans by reining in Washington bureaucrats and freeing up money to invest in hometown projects. Wall Street banks that benefited during the Obama Administration oppose today’s bill because they enjoy the advantages the status quo provides over Michigan community banks and credit unions. I support today’s legislation because it will benefit hardworking Michigan families and the local financial institutions who know our communities best.
Thank you to Midland's own Sam Bork for interning in my office during the spring. He goes to Central Michigan University and I wish him all the best in the future! #FireUpChips
Thank you to Hunter Wilson of Perrinton and Fulton High School for interning in my office this spring. He is a student at The George Washington University and he did a terrific job in the office.

I continue to fight Canada's proposed nuclear waste disposal site on the shore of Lake Huron. I am urging the State Department to do everything it can to stop this plan and I hope Canada will choose a new location outside the Great Lakes Basin.

Summer is a good time for high school students in mid and northern Michigan to think about what they would like to do after high school. If you know any talented young men and women who would like to attend our nation's military service academies, please have them apply through my office. More information is available at the link below.
James McCloughan's heroic actions saved the lives of 10 Americans. The Medal of Honor is well-deserved!

Today, we pay tribute to the flag of the United States of America.  The Continental Congress first approved the flag in 1777, a year after our country declared its independence and since then it has served as a patriotic symbol of our freedom. Throughout our country’s history it has been updated and it has been seen as a symbol of liberation and hope around the world. Our veterans have fought and died while wearing the flag on their uniforms, and for their courage and sacrifice, they have earned our eternal gratitude.

BREAKING: Today, in an overwhelming bipartisan vote, the House of Representatives passed the Department of Veterans Affairs Accountability and Whistleblower Protection Act of 2017. This legislation is an important part of holding the VA accountable for the care of our veterans. While the majority of VA employees are hardworking, it is vital that we streamline the process for removing those who have failed our veterans. This legislation will help ensure the VA has the best people providing our veterans with the care they earned for serving our country. The House vote was 368-55. The bill now goes to the president for his signature.

This morning, Congressman Moolenaar attended baseball practice. He was uninjured in the shooting that took place. He asks that you keep those injured in this act of cowardice in your thoughts and prayers.

We played the The Congressional Baseball Game for Charity tonight. It was a wonderful evening that reminded us that as Americans there is more that unites us than divides us. Capitol Police Special Agent David Bailey, whose heroic actions saved lives yesterday, was able to throw the first pitch to Roberto Clemente Jr., the son of my baseball hero growing up. Thank you for your support these past two days and please keep Congressman Scalise, Matt Mika, and the injured officers in your prayers.
Congratulations to the Freeland High School Girls Soccer team on making it to the state championship game and a having great season! Freeland Community School District

A good morning in Mount Pleasant today as I presented military service honors to Vietnam War veteran Duane Dishong of Vestaburg. Duane served our country honorably and I enjoyed presenting these awards to him at Post110AmericanLegion where he volunteers. Thank you Duane, for your service to our country.

Thank you to the Humm Family for hosting Dinner on the Farm on Monday night. I enjoyed the opportunity to meet with farmers from across the district and hearing their concerns for our government and our country.

Yesterday, it was announced that Congressman Steve Scalise has been upgraded to fair condition and is beginning a long journey of healing and rehabilitation. Then last night, it was great to see Crystal Griner, a member of his security detail who was injured in the attack, throw out the first pitch for the Congressional Women's Softball Game between members of Congress and the media. Griner saved lives with her courageous actions last week and I continue to keep all those injured in my prayers as they recover.
I have joined my colleagues in introducing legislation that will help fight Asian carp and help protect the Great Lakes.
Great meeting today with Michigan members from National Future Farmers of America. These students represent a bright future for Michigan agriculture!

The finding of Asian carp less than ten miles from Lake Michigan is another alarm bell for action to protect the Great Lakes ecosystem from this invasive species. There is an urgent need for the Army Corps of Engineers to release the Brandon Road Lock and Dam report so further steps can be taken to stop Asian carp from entering the Great Lakes.

Good news announced last week for the Superfund cleanup in St. Louis. This funding is a positive step in the long overdue clean-up process. I will keep the pressure on the EPA to see this clean-up through to the end and restore the Pine River for future generations.
Please be safe this weekend as our region continues to deal with flooding in many areas.

I urge the governor to ask for federal assistance so Midland and Isabella counties and the surrounding region will have access to federal resources to recover and cleanup in response to this flooding.

This morning, I spoke with Acting Regional FEMA Administrator Janet M. Odeshoo. We discussed FEMA's possible assistance in cleanup and recovery from the recent flooding in mid Michigan if the governor makes a request for federal assistance. FEMA continues to monitor the situation and is working closely with state and federal officials. Additionally, I ask residents to continue following the messages of our state and local authorities to stay safe. Residents who have damaged property should report it to their local officials and insurance companies so they can accurately assess the impact of this flooding.  Residents in Midland County should call 989-837-3500.   They can also report damage online at: https://midland911.org/GetHelpWith/CompleteFloodDamageQuestionnaire.aspx.   Residents in Isabella County should call 989-779-1452.   Residents in Saginaw County should go to http://www.saginawcounty.com/News/Saginaw-County-Damage-Assessment-Form-June-23-2017-Floodin.aspx or call 989-790-5500.  Residents in Gladwin County should call 989-426-6871.
Veterans from Post110AmericanLegion in Mount Pleasant recently rode for a great cause!

The Congressional Award is given to young people across America who do good work in their local communities. One of this year's winners is Emily Deese of Midland. She earned the medal for her work leading the construction of the Douglas Sowle Memorial Pavilion in Breckenridge. Congratulations Emily!

Yesterday's decision by the EPA reins in the federal government and it is a victory for the 15,000 farmers in our district. By ending the legal uncertainty created by the Obama Administration's overreaching rule, Michigan farmers will be able to raise their crops and livestock without worrying about the possibility of the federal government coming to regulate ditches and mud puddles on their fields.

FEMA has granted the governor's request to conduct a Preliminary Damage Assessment with state and local officials to review damage caused by recent flooding in Bay, Gladwin, Isabella and Midland counties. I have been in contact with FEMA this week and I welcome the agency’s decision to conduct a preliminary assessment of the damage to determine if federal assistance will be made available.

Today, the House of Representatives passed Kate’s Law. The law is named after Kate Steinle who was killed in 2015 by an illegal immigrant who had been deported five times and convicted of multiple felonies. It keeps dangerous criminals behind bars by increasing the maximum number of years of imprisonment for deported felons who reenter the United States. What happened to Kate was a tragedy. As a public servant, keeping Americans safe is my top priority. I support Kate’s Law because it will keep dangerous criminals behind bars and the increased penalties will help secure the border by serving as a deterrent to those who want to reenter the country illegally.
I hope everyone has a wonderful holiday weekend. It is a great time to give thanks for our independence and to celebrate our country's birthday. Please enjoy a safe and fun weekend!
Happy Independence Day!

NEWS: Today, the House Appropriations Committee, which I serve on, released legislation fully funding the Great Lakes Restoration Initiative in next year's budget. Working with private organizations and our state's leading research universities, the GLRI does vital work across Michigan to protect the Great Lakes and the streams, rivers and lakes that run into them. I have been a long time supporter of the GLRI and it's great to see that this important priority for our state is fully funded. I want to thank my colleagues on the Appropriations Committee for joining me in supporting the Great Lakes.

Busy day in the House Committee on Appropriations - Republicans today. We passed legislation calling for the Brandon Road Lock report to be released to #StopAsianCarpNow. The legislation also helps toward our goal of building a new Soo Lock by making the Army Corps use new standards for its studies. More details below.
A good article about how today's legislation addresses Michigan's priorities on Asian carp, the Soo Locks and more.
It's #NationalFrenchFryDay: Congratulations to Midland Burger Company on having the best fries in Michigan!
Pure Michigan.
Working tonight in a committee meeting where I am supporting legislation that fully funds the Great Lakes Restoration Initiative. The view at my desk:

Hi everyone, here is a quick update on how I have been moving Michigan's priorities, including fully funding Great Lakes protection, forward through my work this month on the House Committee on Appropriations - Republicans.

Today, the governor announced that he is asking the federal government for a major disaster declaration for the state following the severe flooding in mid Michigan last month. I previously called for this decision and I welcome it today. I have been in contact with FEMA since the flooding occurred and the agency has been very responsive, including its preliminary assessment. I hope federal, state and local officials will continue the exemplary work they have done in response to the flooding.
This weekend the U.S. Navy held the commissioning ceremony for the USS Gerald R. Ford - CVN 78. God bless the men and women on board as they serve our country
Thank you to Conner McGuire of Midland for interning in my office this summer. Best wishes to him as he returns to Central Michigan University this fall. #FireUpChips
An overwhelming 419-3 vote today in favor of sanctions on Russia, Iran and North Korea. These sanctions punish those who want to harm us and our allies around the world.

Congratulations to St. Charles Library on receiving a grant from the Saginaw Community Foundation to promote STEM education. STEM education will help students in St. Charles learn the skills they need for the good-paying jobs of the future.
I have joined with my colleagues in the Michigan delegation to support efforts to bring the Air National Guard's F-35 project to our state.

This afternoon I attended a special ceremony at The White House to honor members of the U.S. Capitol Police and the Police Department, City of Alexandria, Virginia for their heroic actions at the Republican baseball practice last month. President Trump awarded the officers the Public Safety Officer Medal of Valor and we celebrated this week's joyous news that Congressman Steve Scalise is out of the hospital. Please continue to keep all the victims in your prayers as they heal and return to their daily lives.
Thank you to Dylan Jaskowski of Roscommon for interning in my office this summer. He did an outstanding job and I wish him all the best as he returns to the  University of Notre Dame this fall.
Thank you to Joseph Ewing for interning in my office this summer. He did an outstanding job!

ICYMI: Members of the Michigan delegation have joined me in writing to the president in support of Governor Snyder's request for federal assistance with the flooding last month. Local and state government has done an outstanding job but cleanup costs are more than they can bear alone. I hope the governor’s request will be granted so federal assistance will be available for our region.

Good News: The Army Corps has announced it will release its Brandon Road report draft on stopping Asian carp from entering Lake Michigan. The announcement comes just one day after the House passed legislation from the Appropriations Committee I serve on calling for the report's release. This is an important priority for our state and a critical step in protecting  the Great Lakes for future generations.

"During the morning darkness of May 15, McCloughan knocked out the RPG position with a grenade. He continued to fight and eliminate enemy soldiers...McCloughan is credited with saving the lives of ten members of his company."  Congratulations to Michigan's own James McCloughan on receiving the Medal of Honor today. It is well-deserved.

Outstanding event in Houghton Lake today honoring Army veteran Stephen Kanachki and Navy veteran Michael Wilson. I presented them with the medals they earned serving our country. Stephen was honored with the Korean Service Defense Medal, Sharpshooter Badge with Rifle Bar and Expert Badge with Carbine Bar. Michael was honored with the National Defense Service Medal, Navy "E" Ribbon, Sea Service Deployment Ribbon and Antarctica Service Medal. Thank you for your service gentlemen!

Today, President Donald Trump approved a major disaster declaration for the state of Michigan. The decision releases federal funds for state and local governments to use in disaster recovery efforts and to help reduce the risk of such an event in the future. In addition, the disaster declaration makes individual assistance available to the countless families still recovering from recent flooding.  Individuals seeking assistance in Bay, Gladwin, Isabella, and Midland Counties and the Saginaw Chippewa Tribe within Isabella County can register with FEMA the following ways: •Apply online at www.DisasterAssistance.gov.   •Constituents may call the registration phone number at 1-800-621-3362; those who have a speech disability or hearing loss and use TTY, should call 1-800-462-7585 directly; for those who use 711 or Video Relay Service (VRS), call 1-800-621-3362.  State and local governments in mid Michigan have done an outstanding job in the aftermath of June's flooding, but the cost of cleanup and recovery was more than they could bear alone. Today's decision to grant federal assistance from FEMA will go a long way toward helping communities and families rebuild.
Nice meetings today with the Montcalm Human Services Coalition and the Ithaca Rotary Club (Michigan).
Started the morning talking with Art Lewis and taking listeners' calls on the issues of the day on WSGW.

I recently presented militay service medals to veterans Stephen Kanachki of Roscommon and Michael Wilson of Houghton Lake. It is an honor to help these veterans get the awards and recognition they deserve. If you or someone you know needs help receiving military medals, please call my office in Midland at 989-631-2552 for assistance.
Congratulations to Arnold Center, Inc. on 50 years of serving the community!

The Army Corps of Engineers just released the Brandon Road draft report on stopping Asian carp and I am reviewing it. You can read it here and comment during the Army Corps' 45-day public comment period.
I recently stopped by the Shiawassee National Wildlife Refuge for a tour with refuge manager Pam Repp. She and her team are doing tremendous work protecting the land for future generations to enjoy.
Nice to see Cops & Doughnuts - Clare City Bakery in Clare profiled on the latest cover of "Country Lines" from HomeWorks Tri-County. Congratulations!

If you need assistance from FEMA Federal Emergency Management Agency, or the U.S. Small Business Administration for damages caused by this summer's flooding you can visit the recovery center that has been set up in Midland. The center is open Monday-Saturday, 8 AM-6 PM. Residents can get more information on disasterassistance.gov or by calling 800-621-3362.

Today, FEMA Federal Emergency Management Agency and the U.S. Small Business Administration opened a disaster recovery center in Mount Pleasant to help residents in need of assistance with this summer's flooding. It is located at 4855 E. Bluegrass Road, Mount Pleasant, MI 48858. Like the recovery center in Midland, it is open 8:00 am to 6:00 pm Monday through Saturday. More details here:

What happened over the weekend in Charlottesville, Virginia was a cruel and cowardly terrorist attack by a white supremacist. I support the Department of Justice’s decision to investigate the incident as a terrorist attack.  As I have said previously, violent rhetoric and actions have no place in our discourse with our fellow Americans. I hope all Americans will pray for those injured in this weekend’s violence, for the families mourning the loss of loved ones and for peace and unity in our country.

In case you missed it last week, the Army Corps of Engineers released the Brandon Road report draft on stopping Asian carp from entering Lake Michigan. There is a 45-day public comment period for all Americans to review the report share their thoughts with the Corps. You can go to the link below to share yours.

Just met up with Congressman Dan Kildee in Birch Run and settled our wager on this year's The Congressional Baseball Game for Charity, buying him a BLT from Tony's I-75. I hope I get to enjoy some Flint coneys next year!
Are you watching the solar eclipse this afternoon? Find out when and how long it will be over your zip code: http://www.freep.com/pages/interactives/eclipse-2017/

William Wilberforce is one of my personal heroes and he was born on this date in 1759. As a Member of Parliament in Great Britain he dedicated his life to abolishing the slave trade, successfully outlawing it in 1807. Here's a short biography where you can learn more about this great man of faith and perseverance.

Today, FEMA Federal Emergency Management Agency announced that its specialists will be at Gill-Roy's Hardware in Midland on Tuesday through Saturday of this week to assist residents recovering from this summer's flooding. See the link below for more information.  Also, there are recovery centers open in the Fourth District to assist residents. They are open Monday through Saturday, 8:00 AM-6:00 PM.   Midland County Carpenter Street School 1407 W. Carpenter St.  Isabella County 4855 E. Bluegrass Road, Mt. Pleasant  Gladwin County 555 West Cedar Road, Gladwin
Nice meeting with the Owosso Rotary Club this afternoon. We covered a lot of important topics including the Great Lakes and agriculture.

Yesterday, the president signed vital legislation for our veterans that will streamline the backlog of appeals at the VA. I voted for this bipartisan legislation and it passed Congress with no opposition. The new law will make an important difference for thousands of veterans who are waiting for answers from the VA.
Our thoughts and prayers this week are with the family and friends of Michigan native Kenneth Smith and all those hurt by this week's tragic accident on the USS John S. McCain (DDG 56).
Man's best friend is always faithful. #semperfi #nationaldogday
The team from the Saginaw River Coast Guard station is doing amazing work in Houston!

Ronnie Monroe served our country as an infantryman in Vietnam. While he was there he was hit in the back by shrapnel and never received the Purple Heart he earned. He recently contacted my office for assistance with getting the Purple Heart, and yesterday I had the honor of presenting it to him in front of his friends and family in a special ceremony in Mesick. Thank you for your service!

Last week I toured the site in Owosso where Cargill is building a new dairy feed production facility. Congratulations to the community on this new development that will create jobs and support Michigan agriculture.

Last week, I  was invited to visit American Mitsuba in Mount Pleasant at the invitation of the company and Consul General Mitsuhiro Wada, Japan's Consul General at its consulate in Detroit. American Mitsuba has been in Mount Pleasant for 30 years and it employs more than 400 people locally. I wish the company years of continued success in the community and thank Consul General Wada for joining me for the tour.

Yesterday, leaders in Montcalm County broke ground on the Belvidere Veterans Memorial Park. The memorial will be an outstanding honor dedicated to those who served our country and the sacrifices they made to defend it.
Happy Labor Day! Best wishes for safe travels in Pure Michigan.
Best wishes to students, parents and teachers for a successful school year!

Reminder: The deadline to request assistance from FEMA for this summer's flooding in mid Michigan is October 2, just a little less than a month away. So far more than 2,000 households have applied and more than $4 million in has been approved. See the link below for more information.

The story below is just one example of Americans coming together in the aftermath of Hurricane Harvey. The selfless generosity of Texans to help one another has inspired people across the country. Today, the House passed more than $7 billion for the FEMA disaster relief fund to help residents in the affected areas rebuild. This fund is used not only in the Texas, but for all emergencies where FEMA is at work, including here in mid Michigan where the agency is helping residents recover from this summer's flooding.

While the House passed more funding today for FEMA's Disaster Relief Fund, Hurricane Irma struck Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands. This massive storm threatens the continental U.S. as well and the team at US National Weather Service Gaylord Michigan has put together this image of what Irma would look like if it was over Michigan. Continue to keep all those affected in your thoughts and prayers in the days and weeks ahead.

As our country continues to recover from Hurricane Harvey and prepares for Hurricane Irma to make landfall in Florida, I supported President Trump’s request for more emergency funding today so FEMA can immediately provide assistance to those in need. I will be keeping all those affected in my thoughts and prayers and I know relief organizations and millions of Americans stand ready to help their fellow Americans. FEMA has helped thousands here in mid Michigan this summer and today’s legislation empowers it to deliver prompt aid in response to the hurricanes.

In case you missed it, just before Labor Day, I had the honor of presenting the Purple Heart to Ronnie Monroe at the AmVets Post in Mesick. Learn more about Ronnie's service and who he plans to give his medal to in this report from 9&10 News.

Today in Saginaw Township, we had a special event to remember 9/11. We will never forget the attacks nor will we forget the heroism of those who gave their lives to save others. Today's event was attended by veterans and first responders who have served our country and our communities and donations were made to the One Percent Veteran Food Pantry. #neverforget
The newest edition of my email newsletter is going out later this week. Sign up today to make sure you get it.

As Michigan's only member on the House Appropriations Committee, I work with my colleagues to advance important priorities for our state. The Facility for Rare Isotope Research at Michigan State University will bring hundreds of good-paying jobs to mid Michigan and I am proud to work on this issue with Rep. Mike Bishop. The House has passed funding for this important project, which you can learn more about in this report from ABC12: Your Trusted Source! WJRT-TV.

The House passed Great Lakes Restoration Initiative funding today. It is fully funded at $300 million. I have been a long-time supporter of this program and I worked on this legislation when it was in my committee. Thank you to all of my colleagues who joined me in supporting this legislation and helping us protect the Lakes for future generations to enjoy.

Dave Maurer at WSGW recently celebrated his 50th anniversary in radio. He is a trusted voice of news and information in our region and that’s why Congressman Dan Kildee and I recently honored him with a special tribute from our offices. Congratulations Dave! Best wishes for many more years of success.
Good luck to everyone participating in this weekend's Liberty Hunt!
On this day in 1787, delegates to the Constitutional Convention in Philadelphia signed the Constitution and sent it to the states for ratification.

Reminder: For folks who need federal assistance for this summer's flooding in mid Michigan, the deadline to register is October 2nd, just two weeks from today. See the link below for more information on how to apply for assistance.

The public comment period for the Brandon Road report on stopping Asian carp has been extended through mid November. So far, more than 1,800 people have made comments to the Army Corps. You can add your voice by commenting at the link below.
Thank you Rich Wells for everything you have done in the community. All the best in the future.

Nice meeting with constituents Dan and Jen Digmann in the Midland office yesterday. We had a good discussion about NIH funding for MS research. NIH research funding is increased in next year's budget in legislation passed by the House last week.

The Air Force marked its 70th birthday earlier this week, honoring the men and women who have taken to the sky in defense of our country. If you know a young man or woman who would like to serve our nation in the Air Force, please let them know my office is currently accepting applications for nominations to the US Air Force Academy (Official) and all of our nation's service academies. More info: https://moolenaar.house.gov/services/military-academy-nominations

#ThrowbackThursday to this past April when Joshua Jacobson from Cadillac brought his Android app to Washington as the winner of the 2016 Congressional App Challenge for our district. This year's contest is now open to all K-12 students in the Fourth District and it's great opportunity for them to learn STEM skills and to practice their coding. Students can enter individually or in groups. Here is The Congressional App Challenge's website with all the details: http://www.congressionalappchallenge.us/

Brooklyn Campau goes to E.F. Rittmueller Middle School in Frankenmuth. While I was in Michigan last month, Brooklyn was visiting Washington D.C. with her grandmother and her cousin. They went on a tour of the Capitol and Brooklyn had the opportunity to sit at my desk.  So today, while I was in Frankenmuth, I stopped by Rittmueller for a short tour with Principal Hecht, and a nice meeting with Brooklyn and her father.
It is wonderful to see Michigan's own Matt Mika recovering so well. Nice pitch at the Detroit Tigers game yesterday!
One week remaining for residents to register with FEMA for assistance with this summer's flooding.
Whenever I see Ken and Veronica, they always tell me stories about their beautiful and beloved grandchildren. My thoughts and prayers are with the Horn family as they mourn the loss of sweet Zellie.

Science, technology, engineering and math education will help all students prepare for the good-paying job opportunities of the future, especially in technical fields and the skilled trades. Michigan has the most talented workforce in the country and I am glad the administration came to our state today to announce these new partnerships that will keep Michigan and the United States ahead of the competition.

Today, I spoke on the House floor and thanked my colleaugues for fully funding the Great Lakes Restoration Initiative. The House passed full funding on September 14th for next year's budget. This funding will protect the Great Lakes for future generations!

Tax reform is about jobs, economic growth and simplicity. I support this new tax reform effort because it will let Michigan families keep more of their hard-earned money and simplify tax filing. I thank the vice president for bringing this important message to Michigan today.

This morning, my friend, Congressman Steve Scalise, returned to the House of Representatives for the first time since he was injured in the attack on the Republican baseball practice on June 14. He gave a wonderful speech and he spoke of the "true angels" that saved his life. I wish him all the best as he continues his recovery and I hope we can be together on the ball field next year.
Had a great start to the day this morning speaking at the Mt. Pleasant Area Chamber of Commerce's Legislative Breakfast.
My prayers today are with the victims of the horrific attack in Las Vegas, and for their families, friends, and the first responders who are bravely on the scene.

Ray Aldrich of Evart served our country in Vietnam. He rose to the rank of Sergeant and twice earned the Good Conduct Medal. It was an honor to present the medal to him and his wife on Friday. Thank you for your service!
It's wonderful to see Alma College giving back to the community with a full-tuition scholarship program for Gratiot County residents.
Thank you to Ali Nunn of Midland for interning in my office this summer. I wish her all the best as she pursues her degree at Michigan State University.
Thank you to Rachel Hill of Midland for interning in my office this summer! All the best as she continues her studies at Alma College this fall.

The Congressional App Challenge is open to all K-12 students in the Fourth District and it's great opportunity for them to learn STEM skills and to practice their coding. Students can enter individually or in groups of up to four students. Here is The Congressional App Challenge's website with all the details: http://www.congressionalappchallenge.us/

This week the House passed Micah’s Law, to prohibit the abortion of babies after 20 weeks of pregnancy. The legislation is named after five-year old Micah Pickering of Iowa City, Iowa who was born when his mother was 22 weeks pregnant. All children have an inalienable right to life and this legislation will protect the unborn, our society’s most vulnerable people, from abortion.
Congratulations to Joan Larsen on her nomination moving forward in the Senate. I hope the full Senate will confirm her very soon.

It was nice to see Dave Camp and Northwood University President Keith Pretty this morning at the Northwood University International Auto Show. The Auto Show is a terrific event for our community and the students do a great job every year.
Who are you cheering for tonight? The University of Michigan and Michigan State University were proudly supported when my team and I took this picture for March Madness earlier this year.
Did you know you can have a flag flown over the Capitol to commemorate a special event? Find out how you can order flags from my office at the link below.

A couple of weeks ago, I presented military service medals to Ray Aldrich of Evart. As Ray told the Cadillac News,  he reached out to my office after he learned he could receive medals for his service to our country. I was honored to help Ray and I would be honored to help any veteran in the Fourth District receive their medals. If you need assistance, please reach out to my office in Midland at 989-631-2552.
Good morning! It's National Farmers Day, a good reminder to give thanks for the people who raise and grow the food we put on our tables.

The United States Naval Academy marked the 172nd anniversary of its founding yesterday. My office is accepting applications from high school seniors for nominations to this prestigious academy as well as the other military service academies. See my website for more information on this opportunity: https://moolenaar.house.gov/services/military-academy-nominations
Happy Anniversary to Amy, my lovely wife of 22 years. With gratitude for our life together, our family and foundation in Christ.   Love,  John

Today, our state mourns the passing of a great philanthropist. Helen DeVos made important contributions to children’s health and the arts in our state and she will be remembered for the many ways she made a positive difference in the community. My prayers go out to her friends and family today.

Earlier this year, the EPA announced good news for the Pine River with initial funding of $9.7 million for the Superfund site in St. Louis. Today, I met with leaders from the EPA and the Citizens Action Group and received an update on the cleanup.

This morning I gave the keynote address at Central Michigan University's 4th Annual Great Lakes Symposium. I talked about the strong bipartisan support in Congress for the Great Lakes Restoration Initiative and protecting the Lakes from invasive species. CMU does critical critical wetlands research funded by the GLRI and I am proud to support it.
Condolences to the Roscommon County Sheriff's office on the loss of a trusted partner who always had their six. Yeff was man's best friend to the end.

I am currently accepting applications for congressional internships in my Washington, D.C. office for winter 2018. The internship program is open to college students and recent graduates who are interested in learning more about our country’s legislative process and the day-to-day operations of a congressional office. Intern responsibilities include conducting tours of the U.S. Capitol, constituent data entry, researching federal legislation and assisting legislative staff. Interns will also have the opportunity to attend legislative briefings and congressional hearings on Capitol Hill. Applicants are asked to provide a cover letter, resume and any specific legislative issues or areas of interest. Applications should be submitted by close of business on Friday, November 10. For more information and to apply for the winter semester, please visit https://moolenaar.house.gov/internships

Michigan connections are all over the World Series, which begins tonight. The Astros are led by Tigers fan favorite Justin Verlander and the Dodgers have players who starred in mid Michigan for the Great Lakes Loons, including Clayton Kershaw, Cory Seager, Kenley Jensen and Ross Stripling. Who are you cheering for in the Series?

Earlier this year, American Otto Warmbier was tortured and killed by the regime in North Korea. Today, I voted for the Otto Warmbier Act to sanction those in China who support North Korea's tyranny and its dangerous pursuit of nuclear weapons. These sanctions are a clear message to the world that anyone who does business with North Korea will face serious consequences.

Today, the House of Representatives moved forward on tax reform, passing a resolution that will allow Congress to overhaul the tax code for the first time since 1986. While others defend the broken status quo, I am fighting for tax reform that will expand the child tax credit and give hardworking Michigan families, farmers and small business owners a pay raise by letting them keep more of their hard-earned money. Work will continue on tax reform in the weeks ahead but today’s vote is a step toward this goal and I will continue to support efforts to make taxes simpler and fairer for all.

Read more about my visit to Central Michigan University last week and my speech to the students at the Institute for Great Lakes Research. I will continue to be an advocate for the GLRI research done at CMU.  "Moolenaar praised the researchers within the IGLR, which he recognized as being “on the front lines of understanding the ways the lakes, tributaries and wetlands come together as one ecosystem. Its research is a great asset to scientists and the general public.'"

DEADLINE: Wednesday, November 1 is the deadline for The Congressional App Challenge. The Challenge is open to all K-12 students in the Fourth District and it's great opportunity for them to learn STEM skills and to practice their coding. Students from Cadillac High School, Midland High School, and Perry High School have already entered and I hope more enter in the days ahead! Students can enter individually or in groups of up to four. Here is The Congressional App Challenge's website with all the details: http://www.congressionalappchallenge.us/

It's National Drug Take Back Day. An opportunity for folks in Mid and Northern Michigan to turn in unused prescription drugs. The opioid crisis has touched the entire country and our communities are not immune. That's why I supported the 21st Century Cures Act with $1 billion to fight opioid addiction. I will continue to work with federal, state and local leaders to fight this epidemic.

Final deadline: The deadline for the The Congressional App Challenge is this Wednesday. All K-12 students in the Fourth District are invited to submit their entries. I look forward to seeing the apps the students turn in this year! http://www.congressionalappchallenge.us/

As part of Down Syndrome Awareness Month last week, one of my subcommittees heard powerful testimony from Frank Stephens on why "my life is worth living." As I told Frank last week, this is one of the best speeches I have heard in Congress. I hope you will take a moment to listen to his message.
Hope everyone has a safe and happy Halloween!

Today’s heinous attack in New York City is a reminder that our country must remain vigilant against threats of terrorism. I pray tonight for the victims and their families. The American people are resilient and I know we will never let terrorism defeat us.

Congratulations to our state's own Joan Larsen on being confirmed to Sixth Circuit Court of Appeals. She is highly recommended by her colleagues, even those who disagree with her politically. She clerked for the late Justice Antonin Scalia and she will be an outstanding federal judge.

Today, the House of Representatives passed the Championing Healthy Kids Act of 2017. The legislation extends the Children’s Health Insurance Program through 2022 and also reauthorizes federally qualified health care centers that provide health care services to residents in the Fourth District.  In fact, there are 18 federally qualified health care centers our district serving more than 150,000 patients. I have been to a number of them, including the one in Houghton Lake pictured below, and seen firsthand the services they provide for residents of all ages. Our rural communities face unique health care challenges and today's legislation will help them best serve the people of mid and northern Michigan.
Yesterday's tragedy in Texas is heartbreaking and we mourn those who lost their lives as they gathered in a place of worship.

Last month I met with Amanda Larrega and her mother, Marcie, to talk about Down Syndrome awareness and the challenges children and parents face. Amanda was full of love and joy and it was the wonderful to meet with her.

Reminder: The Brandon Road Lock draft report was released after the House passed legislation from my committee. This report helps us understand the best ways to stop Asian carp from entering the Great Lakes. The Army Corps is still accepting comments on this report through November 16. You can make your comments at the link below.
Congratulations to Joel Johnson and Jason Allen on their appointments. They will do a great job for Michigan agriculture!
On this week in 1984, President Reagan won reelection, carrying 49 states and winning 525 electoral votes. Here's the front page of  The Argus-Press in Owosso from 33 years ago today.
Happy 242nd Birthday to the U.S. Marine Corps!

David Wright, born and raised in Ithaca, is a retired Army sergeant who was wounded in Vietnam. While leading his platoon on Valentine's Day in 1969 he was hit by enemy fire, but he held his exposed position while tending to his wounds. This move allowed his fellow soldiers to make it to safety and then he joined them. David is a selfless hero and it was a privlege to present the Purple Heart Medal to him today. VFW Post 1454 Alma MI
To our veterans, today and everyday, thank you for your service.

Wonderful keynote speech on Saturday at the Midland Veterans Day ceremony by Iraq War veteran Col. Rhoda K. Daniel. She has served in the Army for 32 years and been awarded the Bronze Star Medal. Thank you to her for her leadership and to all our veterans for their service to our country.

Final Reminder: This Wednesday is the deadline for high school seniors to submit their applications to my office for nominations to our nation's service academies. Members of Congress may nominate candidates for appointment to four of the five U.S. service academies: U.S. Military Academy, West Point, NY; the U.S. Naval Academy, Annapolis, MD; the U.S. Air Force Academy, Colorado Springs, CO; and the U.S. Merchant Marine Academy, Kings Point, NY.  Details about the application process are online at https://moolenaar.house.gov/.
Michigan Farm Bureau reports on a new dairy facility coming to Greenville. Another great development for Michigan agriculture.
Hope everyone has a safe hunt this year. Good luck!

Yesterday, I sat down with Rep. Debbie Dingell to talk about civility for The Faith & Politics Institute. In Washington, our offices are across the hall from each other. We work together when we can and when we disagree we never attack each other personally. With big issues facing our country today, I hope all Americans will do the same.

The tax relief legislation passed by the House yesterday provides real tax relief for middle class families. It doubles the standard deduction for married couples to $24,000. A family of four with the median income of $59,000 will see their tax bill be cut by more than $1,000 next year.

Today, we are one step closer to providing tax relief for middle class families and Main Street, and ending the broken status quo. The House voted for tax relief and if the legislation becomes law it will mean bigger paychecks, more jobs and a simpler, fairer system that closes loopholes. It will be a tax cut for Michigan families and keep more money here at home in our local communities.

The facts are clear: Today's tax relief legislation will benefit hardworking, middle-class families here in mid and northern Michigan. The bill doubles the standard deduction for married couples. It also increases the child tax credit by 60 percent, letting more than 40,000 people in our district keep more of their own money at home to provide for their children.

In case you missed it last week, here is WNEMTV5news's coverage of the Purple Heart presentation for David Wright of Ithaca. It was a great afternoon and I am glad I could help David and his family cut through the red tape to receive the honors he earned defending our country.
Happy Thanksgiving!

A wonderful event today to honor Gail and Rachel Locke as this year's Angels in Adoption. Together, Gail and his wife Rachel have opened their home and helped foster more than 150 kids over the last 25 years. They have provided a loving place for children in our community to learn and grow. Thank you to Judge Dorene Allen, and Michigan Supreme Court Justices Kurtis Wilder and Beth Clement for recognizing these outstanding individuals. Congratulations to the Lockes as this year's Angels in Adoption!

It's championship weekend for high school football. Good luck to the  Ithaca Yellowjackets, Swan Valley Athletics, Nouvel Football, and Pewamo-Westphalia Pirate Football as they play for state titles on Friday and Saturday at Ford Field.
Rep. Debbie Dingell and I recently discussed what we're thankful for this year and the important role of civility and community in our country.

On Thanksgiving, we are thankful for the men and women in our military and the first responders here at home who work hard to protect us everyday. This year, I am especially thankful for United States Capitol Police Special Agents David Bailey (pictured below) and Crystal Griner who acted quickly to save the lives of my colleagues at the baseball practice in June. All of our service members and first responders make sacrifices for our country and our communities. Thank you for your service and Happy Thanksgiving!
Congratulations to Pewamo-Westphalia Pirate Football on winning the state championship!

On Monday, I went to the Mecosta-Osceola Career Center to see the outstanding work happening there. It's a terrific place for students to prepare for the job opportunities of the future in many industries.
In case you missed it last week, here is a wonderful article about Gail and Rachel Locke, this year's Congressional Angels in Adoption for the Fourth District. Congratulations again!

#ThrowbackThursday: Congratulations to Judge Ken Tacoma of Cadillac on receiving the Daniel J. Wright Lifetime Achievement Award for Exemplary Service to Michigan’s Children and Families from the Michigan Supreme Court. Here's a picture from 2015, when Ken was honored with the Angels in Adoption award and he and his wife Cathy came to Washington for the ceremony. I wish Ken all the best in his retirement.

Here's an article from the Big Rapids Pioneer with more about my visit to the Mecosta-Osceola Career Center this week. The skills the students learn at the center will help our state maintain its world-leading manufacturing base.

This morning at Midland High School, I presented first place for The Congressional App Challenge in the Fourth District to Gerard Bringard, Emma Jamrog, Preston Millward and Gwynne Ozkan. Their hard work and ingenuity led to their success in this year's challenge. They have designed an outstanding app for campus safety and you can learn more about it by watching the video they made:  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=i2nUjjqN98M

Congratulations to Sergeant Mark Moore and Deputy Jed Avery of the Osceola County Sheriff's Office: Michigan for their Life Saving Awards. Thank you for your service to the community and keeping all of us safe.
Pearl Harbor Day reminds us of the incredible sacrifices the Greatest Generation made to defeat tyranny and to preserve freedom around the world.

Al Blinke has been in broadcast news for 40 years and now he is retiring after 13 years at WNEMTV5news. I dropped by the station a few weeks ago and thanked Al for his work to bring news and information to residents across mid Michigan.

Did you know the Palestinian Authority has been paying the families of suicide bombers that kill Israelis? Today, the House passed legislation that will end funding for the Palestinian Authority until it stops these outrageous payments. Only after the Palestinian Authority stops giving money to the families of terrorists can it again be a partner for peace in the region.

On Monday, the United States Department of Agriculture declared crop disaster designations for counties in Michigan’s Fourth Congressional District for excessive rain that occurred this year. The counties named are: Clinton, Gladwin, Gratiot, Isabella, Midland, Montcalm, Saginaw, and Shiawassee.  Farmers in these counties are eligible to be considered for assistance from the Farm Service Agency, including emergency loans. Farm operators have eight months from the date of the disaster designation to apply for assistance. More information is available for farmers at local Farm Service Agency offices.

Today, the House of Representatives passed the Concealed Carry Reciprocity Act.  The legislation also updates the National Instant Criminal Background Check System and increases assistance to states so they can increase the number of records submitted into the system. As always, I strongly support the Second Amendment rights of all Americans. Just as a driver’s license is valid across state lines, this legislation will allow those who have valid permits to carry across state lines. The bill also improves the background check system so states will submit more records and help stop those who are already legally prohibited from buying a gun.

Last week, I had the opportunity to speak on the phone with Astronaut Andrew Feustel. He is from Michigan and in March he will be going to the International Space Station on his third spaceflight. I wish him all the best and thank him for his service.

New Law: Today, the biggest pay raise for our troops in eight years became the law of the land. The president signed the National Defense Authorization Act giving our soldiers a well-deserved raise and increasing benefits for them and their families. The legislation also increases funding for national security, so our military has the resources it needs to win on the battlefield and keep our country safe.

Next year, Congress will be debating the Farm Bill. This legislation will protect our country's food security and will be crucial to our farmers and rural communities. I will be fighting for our state’s agriculture priorities and you can let me know your concerns on this issue on my website: https://moolenaar.house.gov/contact/email
Please stay safe during the winter storm today.
On this day 226 years ago, the Bill of Rights was ratified, ensuring our fundamental rights and freedoms as Americans.
Many in Michigan have enjoyed this year's deer hunt. Here is a nice story about one local hunter's determination to overcome his accident and participate in our state's incredible outdoor heritage.
The Army Corps must not delay its report on Asian carp.

Saddened today to hear of the passing of Sam Ortisi. He worked hard and he lived the American Dream. His customers have fond memories of him serving them at his restaurant and he will be missed by all. Rest in peace.

This afternoon, the House will vote on middle-class tax relief that will benefit hardworking Michigan families. A doubled standard deduction means Michigan families will keep more of their own money tax-free. Here are more details about what is in the bill.

Folks from across mid and northern Michigan have told me what the $2,000 child tax credit will mean to them. This includes grandparents and retirees who want to see our young families thrive and they know this will help hardworking parents.

Michigan residents are already benefiting from tax reform. Today, AT&T announced it will give $1,000 bonuses to 200,000 employees including 5,000 here in Michigan. Then this afternoon, Fifth Third Bank announced it will raise wages and give bonuses to its employees including those at locations across the Fourth District. Hardworking Michiganders are seeing higher wages and more money because of the tax reform passed this week.

Michigan small business owners are taxed on their business profits that pass through to them as personal income, often at rates as high as 39%. Tax reform passed by Congress will mean the effective tax rate for small businesses would be no more than 29%. Small business owners have told me what this cut will mean for them and their employees and they mirror the announcements made by AT&T and Fifth Third yesterday that directly credit tax reform for the bonuses and higher wages they are paying to their frontline employees.
Christmastime at the Capitol

Dick Enberg, the legendary sports announcer and an alum of Central Michigan University, passed away last night. He was the voice of many major events including the 1979 NCAA Men's Basketball Championship Game between Magic Johnson and Larry Bird. He was beloved by fans for his work, including his catchphrase, "Oh my!" He leaves behind an incredible legacy of accomplishments and he never forgot his alma mater which presents the Dick Enberg Alumni Commitment Award each year. Rest in peace.
It was wonderful to attend the bipartisan Christmas party at the White House a few weeks ago. My wife and I and our entire family wish you a Merry Christmas!

A few weeks ago, I interviewed terrific high school seniors from our district who have applied for nomination to our nation’s military academies through my office. These bright young students want to serve our country and this special video that aired before this month's Army/Navy game is a wonderful reminder of the commitment they are willing to make.   “They’ve all waited to get the same word. To get word that they’ve been chosen. Chosen to sacrifice. To dedicate. To serve.”
I hope you and your family have a blessed 2017!
REMINDER: Office hours are being held in January and they are great way to get help with a federal agency like the VA or the IRS. No appointment is necessary. See the link for times and locations.
It was fun to have my granddaughter join me on the House floor today for this special moment during the swearing-in of the new Congress.

BREAKING: I have just been named to the House Appropriations Committee. I am the first member from Michigan to be named to the committee since 2011. On Appropriations, I will have the important responsibility of overseeing government spending. I will fight to make sure government uses taxpayer dollars wisely, stays within its means, and is accountable to the needs of Michigan’s hardworking families. I am excited to get started on this new assignment.

UPDATE: Tonight, I voted to rebuke the Obama Administration for abandoning Israel at the United Nations last month. The administration's decision to abstain damaged decades of steadfast American support for Israel. The world must know that the U.S. government and the American people stand with Israel.

Last night, the House passed legislation that will prohibit any future administration - Republican or Democratic - from implementing major regulations without a vote of approval from Congress. After the last eight years, Americans are tired of executive decrees that impose major burdens on their lives. The REINS Act strengthens Congress’s role as the writer of our nation’s laws and it will hold the federal bureaucracy accountable.

Last week I joined my colleagues in reading the Constitution on the House floor and read the part that gives states a role in ratifying amendments. The Constitution is the cornerstone of our government and as I pledged when I took the oath of office, I will do everything I can to support it.

Today is Law Enforcement Appreciation Day. I extend my gratitude to the men and women serving our communities and our state everyday. They do a terrific job keeping us safe and their sacrifice is never forgotten. #LawEnforcementAppreciationDay #ThankACop

The USDA has declared crop disaster designations for all 15 counties in Michigan’s Fourth Congressional District. Farm operators in these counties are eligible to be considered for certain assistance from the Farm Service Agency, including emergency loans. More information is available at local Farm Service Agency offices.   Michigan’s Fourth Congressional District is made up of the following counties: Clare, Clinton, Gladwin, Gratiot, Isabella, Mecosta, Midland, Missaukee, Montcalm, Ogemaw, Osceola, Roscommon, Saginaw, Shiawassee and Wexford.

Our nation's World War II veterans are the greatest generation and this past Veterans Day, I had the honor of presenting Cecil "Tommy" Thompson with the French Legion of Honor Medal. It was a terrific celebration and I enjoyed getting to know Tommy and his family. Sadly, Tommy passed away on January 2nd. I offer my condolences and prayers to his family and I hope you'll take a moment to read this nice story about his service to our country: http://www.ourmidland.com/lifestyles/article/1st-Lt-Cecil-Tommy-Thompson-6955546.php
Today was the last broadcast for WLNS Jane Aldrich, who has been a favorite of viewers in Mid Michigan for more than three decades. Congratulations to her on retirement! WLNS-TV

Today, I voted in support of a resolution that will allow Congress to repeal the Affordable Care Act, an unaffordable health care law that has created fewer health insurance choices and higher costs for Americans. Today’s vote is a first step toward creating a health care system that puts patients first.

Today we honor Reverend Doctor Martin Luther King Jr. for his life of service. He believed in the promise of America's founding documents, fought for what is right and made our country better for all Americans.
Great to be on WSGW with Art Lewis this morning to take listeners' calls and talk about the important issues facing our country.

This morning's listening session in Cadillac has been postponed due to today's inclement weather in northern Michigan and will be rescheduled. My listening sessions today in Stanton, St. Johns, and Owosso will still occur as planned.
Gene Cernan made great contributions to our nation's efforts to explore space, serving as an astronaut from 1963 through 1976. He is an American hero and our country mourns his passing.
It was great to hear from constituents at the three listening sessions I held in the Fourth District yesterday.  Here are pictures from Stanton, St. Johns and Owosso.

Students from DeWitt High School stopped by the office today as part of their visit to Washington, D.C for the inauguration. It's great to have the students here to see history and the peaceful transition of power! #Inauguration
In 15 hours we will witness a peaceful transfer of power and have a new president.
Wonderful to see that Brooke Emery, a Mount Pleasant native and CMU graduate, will be a part of today's Inauguration ceremony as a member of the U.S. Air Force Band. #fireupchips

It was an honor to witness the historic and peaceful transfer of power at the Capitol today. Best wishes to President Donald Trump and his family as he takes on the enormous responsibilities and duties as our nation's president and commander-in-chief.
A nice story in The Argus-Press about another company growing and expanding in Mid Michigan.
Congratulations to the Michigan State Police troopers from the posts in Freeland and Mount Pleasant! Thank you for all you do for our communities.

In 2015, I voted for the Keystone XL Pipeline, along with a bipartisan majority including 28 Democrats. I support today's decision to move forward with Keystone because building the pipeline will create good-paying jobs and provide hardworking Americans with a more stable source of energy.

This afternoon, the House voted to permanently ban taxpayer funding for abortion. This policy has been renewed every year and today's vote would make it permanent. I spoke on the House floor in support of this law.

Happy 180th Birthday to our wonderful state! On this day in 1837, Michigan became the 26th state to be admitted to the Union. Here's a popular graphic I shared last year showing all 50 dates of statehood.
Here is a report from The Daily News about my recent listening session in Stanton, where we talked about health care, education and jobs.

Tony Gojcaj was a friend and a brilliant chef. He always had a big smile on his face and he always made others smile with his delicious meals. He and his restaurants have made outstanding contributions to the communities of mid and northern Michigan and I will miss him dearly. My prayers go out to his family and friends.

Constituent relations representatives will be holding office hours throughout the district in February. These hours are a great way to get assistance with a federal agency like the VA and IRS. See the link for times and locations.

Thank you to the more than 50 students from Valley Lutheran High School, Saginaw who participated in the #MarchForLife today. It is a great sign for our country that so many students are part of the #prolifegeneration.  #whywemarch
Congratulations to Michigan State Police Motor Carrier Officer Daniel Priebe of Lakeview for earning the Motor Carrier Officer of the Year Award!

BREAKING: Congratulations to Judge Neil Gorsuch on his nomination to the Supreme Court. From what we know, it looks like he is a solid nominee. The Senate has a constitutional responsibility to provide advice and consent on Supreme Court nominations. It should review Judge Gorsuch’s record and qualifications to see if he will be a rule of law justice who is right for this important spot on the high court.

It was great to see friends from Michigan Wheat today and to be honored with the "2016 Wheat Advocate" award. Our state's farmers do a terrific job putting food on the tables of families locally and around the world. Thank you for this recognition.

I am fighting against the proposed nuclear waste site on the Canadian side of Lake Huron. Lake Huron is a treasure between our two countries and I hope the government of Canada will look for a new location outside of the Great Lakes Basin.

In the last months of the Obama Administration, the Social Security Administration proposed a rule that would take away the Second Amendment rights of Americans. Today, I voted to overturn that rule. The Second Amendment rights of Americans shall not be infringed and they should not be taken away by bureaucrats.
On this day in 1911, Ronald Reagan was born in Tampico, Illinois. He was a terrific president who communicated with humor and grace and we are so grateful that he led our country for eight years.
On this day in 1809, Abraham Lincoln was born in Kentucky. His leadership saved our country and his eloquence inspires us today. He is my favorite president and I will always admire his character.

Jim and Jack Winkel of Missaukee County are this year's recipients of the Dairy Farmer of the Year award from MSU Animal Science! Their family farm was founded by their grandfather 1899. Congratulations to Jim and Jack on this award!
ICYMI: GM announced a $20 million investment this week. This is good news for mid Michigan and the Great Lakes Bay Region.
Had a good discussion today about the future of American Indian higher education with President Carla Sineway and students from Saginaw Chippewa Tribal College.

On Monday, the House passed the Email Privacy Act of 2017. I supported this legislation because our email privacy laws were long overdue for an update. This new law protects the privacy of Michigan residents while still providing law enforcement agencies the tools they need to keep us safe.

This morning, I sat down with Michigan members of the National Border Patrol Council. We must ensure they - and all law enforcement - have the tools necessary to complete their mission safely. I want to thank these Michiganders for their hard work at our state's border crossings.

Thank you to the group from YOUTHINKMontcalm for coming to the Capitol today to talk about the substance abuse issues they are seeing in their community. Keep up the good work you're doing, especially for our youth.
Thank you to constituents from Clare County and their friends who came to the office today to talk about Parent Project Muscular Dystrophy. #EndDuchenne

This morning I met with Michigan supporters of the Special Olympics, including Hannah and Jaely who are on their high school's unified basketball team. I enjoyed hearing from them and I appreciate the great work the Special Olympics do in Michigan and around the country to build bridges and opportunities for individuals with special needs.
Hi everyone, here is a quick update on the week. Thanks for watching.
Members First Credit Union has been in our community for 80 years and I appreciated the opportunity to provide an update at its event today in Midland.

If you missed last week's telephone town hall meeting, here is where you can hear constituents' questions for and against the Affordable Care Act. We also discussed Russia, the critical infrastructure needs of the Soo Locks, and more.

Today, I presented military service medals to Korean War veteran Ralph Wallace of Paris at Amvets Post 1941 in Big Rapids. It was a special event and I was honored to make the presentation. Thank you to Ralph and all of our veterans for their service and sacrifice to our nation.

It was great to be at the Midland Center for the Arts yesterday to congratulate Bruce Winslow on his retirement. Bruce has done a terrific job as director and he has also served as a judge for our district’s Congressional Art Competition. Thank you to Bruce for his discerning eye for outstanding art and his service to our community.

I had a great day in the district, attending meetings and answering questions. I spoke with WNEMTV5news in Midland, went to the Breckenridge Rotary meeting at Noon, met with The Saginaw News, and toured the Michigan Cardiovascular Institute.
Good luck to Erik Jones Racing of Byron today as he makes his first start in the Daytona 500!

Today was a win for Michigan farmers. The president ordered the EPA to begin the process of eliminating the Waters of the U.S. rule that was finalized in 2015.
