This rule has always been strongly opposed by farmers because it went too far and could have resulted in EPA agents coming to farmers’ fields to regulate mud puddles and ditches. That is why I promised to fight it when I first ran to serve the people of mid and northern Michigan. By withdrawing this regulation, the EPA will be better able to focus on its core mission of ensuring clean water and protecting the Great Lakes from invasive species.
Congratulations to Calvary Baptist Academy on winning its third straight girls' basketball state championship this past weekend!

I am currently accepting applications for congressional internships in my Washington, D.C. office for summer 2017. The internship program is open to college students and recent graduates who are interested in learning more about our country’s legislative process and the day-to-day operations of a congressional office. Intern responsibilities include conducting tours of the U.S. Capitol, constituent data entry, researching federal legislation and assisting legislative staff. Interns will also have the opportunity to attend legislative briefings, congressional hearings and receptions on Capitol Hill. Applicants are asked to provide a cover letter, resume and any specific legislative issues or areas of interest.  Applications should be submitted by close of business on Friday, March 31. For more information and to apply for the summer semester, please visit https://moolenaar.house.gov/internships

I am saddened to learn of the passing of Tim Brockman. Tim was an outstanding citizen, who gave of his time and resources to make life better for all residents of Isabella County. He was a part of countless local organizations, clubs and special projects and he never stopped working to make a positive difference in the community.

Today, Attorney General Jeff Sessions announced he would recuse himself from any current and future investigations into foreign interference in the 2016 election. I called for him to do this earlier today and I believe his decision is an important step toward ensuring that the FBI’s investigation is independent and has the trust of the American people.

I have signed a letter asking the president to release the Asian carp plan for the Brandon Road Lock and Dam in Illinois. Asian carp are a threat to the Great Lakes and action needs to be taken to prevent them from harming the ecosystem.

Today, I honored Cadillac High School's Joshua Jacobson as the winner of the Congressional App Challenge in our district. Joshua’s hard work, ingenuity, and technical know-how will help him go far in whatever he pursues next. Congratulations!

Today, the House of Representatives passed legislation that includes full funding for a pay increase for our men and women in uniform, who confront threats abroad so we don't have to face danger here at home. This legislation provides our soldiers with the equipment they need to win on the battlefield and gives them and their families a well-deserved pay raise.

On Monday, I had a good day in the district. I started in Reed City for a legislative breakfast of the Mecosta, Osceola and Wexford Farm Bureaus. I then visited 9&10 News for a tour of its new office, met with the Cadillac News, and visited Life Resources of Northern Michigan. To end the day, I toured MidMichigan Health's federally qualified health center in Houghton Lake.
This morning, I heard from Department of Homeland Security Secretary John Kelly and received an update on how his department is securing the border and working to keep our country safe.

Patrick Curry, President of Fullerton Tool Company in Saginaw and Mike Coast, President of the Michigan Manufacturing Technology Center were in DC earlier this week. Fullerton is a third-generation, family-owned business, that with workforce skill development from the MMTC, has grown into a leader in precision-made tooling. Congratulations on decades of sucess, all made in America!

I am saddened that this week's wind storm killed Midland resident Max Muessig and his girlfriend, Maggie Potter. My prayers for their families and all those who are recovering from the storm this week.

This morning I started the day in Gladwin with an interview on 103 Country, then reading to the outstanding preschoolers at Mid Michigan Community Action Agency, and then discussing small businesses issues with Dan Mercer, the owner of Pepper Mill. After that, I did an interview with Sunny 97.7 in Midland.

The annual Congressional Art Competition is open to Fourth District high school students. The winning student will have his or her art displayed in the U.S. Capitol for a year and receive two round-trip tickets to travel to Washington, D.C for an annual event with competition winners from around the country.  Regional winners from the Fourth District will have the opportunity for their art to appear in the Midland and Cadillac offices. See the link for more details and please encourage talented high school artists you know to enter the competition.

Had a great meeting today with more than 20 farmers from the Fourth District. We have a lot of agricultural diversity in Michigan and the farmers talked about cash crops, dairy, and even honeybees. Michigan Farm Bureau

The health care debate continues to be one of the most important issues facing Congress and the American people. I have pledged to repeal the current failed health care law that raised premiums and deductibles, effectively leaving many Americans with coverage they can't really use. I am reviewing the new legislation and I have received a lot of input from constituents through meetings, letters, emails and phone calls. The legislative process for the bill has been very deliberative with hours and hours of debate in three committees. Another committee will review the bill before it is up for a vote of the whole House. Additionally, many members have met with the Administration and leaders in the House to offer ideas on improving the legislation and changes are still possible. If you would like to read the current version of the legislation, you can see it on readthebill.gop.

I have always been a strong supporter of funding for the Great Lakes Restoration Initiative. I believe that this year there will once again be great support in the House of Representatives for the GLRI. I am working to protect the Great Lakes on a number of issues and you can read more about them in this op-ed I sent out today to newspapers in our district.

Today, I voted for legislation that reaffirms veterans' Second Amendment rights, so they will not be taken away by a bureaucrat at the VA.   Current practice at the VA takes away a veteran’s Second Amendment rights if they appoint a fiduciary to handle their financial affairs because the VA reports the veteran as being “mentally incompetent” to the FBI’s National Criminal Background Check System.   That designation could result in veterans being blocked from legally purchasing a firearm. A veteran may apply for relief through the VA, but that puts a bureaucrat at the department in charge of making the final decision on a veteran’s Second Amendment rights.  Americans’ treasure their constitutional rights and the Second Amendment is no exception. There is already a legal process through the courts to prohibit the mentally ill from buying firearms. That decision belongs in the judicial branch, and not in the hands of bureaucrats at the VA, a department that has mistreated so many of our nation’s heroes.
Like many families in mid and northern Michigan, the D.C. staff is divided! Who are you rooting for today?

I worked across the aisle in the House to fight for this aid for Flint and it was approved by Congress in December. I am glad the EPA is making this much-needed money available to help Flint rebuild its critical water infrastructure. This funding should be put to use immediately and in the most effective manner possible so the people of Flint will have clean drinking water as soon as possible.

This week, the House passed two pieces of legislation to help our veterans. Our veterans deserve the best care and these bills will make it easier for the VA to retain and promote excellent employees, and to remove poorly performing ones who are failing our heroes. The VA received a budget increase this year and these reforms will make sure the VA has the best employees to carry out its critical mission.

Last week, farmers from the Fourth District and across the state organized a relief convoy to help ranchers in Texas and Kansas who lost hay and livestock in recent wildfires there. This video from Michigan Farm Bureau shares more details about the generous spirit of those who came together in Durand to make it all happen.
Today is National #AgDay! Our district has 10,000 farms and 15,000 farmers and each of them contributes to #PureMichigan. Thank you farmers for all you do for our communities and our state.

Today is World Water Day. Obviously, the health of the Great Lakes is critical to the past, present and future of our state. You can read about my efforts to protect the Great Lakes in this op-ed I wrote last week.
